    Order read for consideration in Committee of Supply [3rd Allotted Day].

[Mr Speaker in the Chair]



    Head Q -

    The Chairman: Head Q - Ministry of Home Affairs. Amendment No. (1), Prof. Chin.

    Assoc. Prof. Chin Tet Yung (Sembawang): Sir, I beg to move,

    That the total sum to be allocated for Head Q of the Main Estimates be reduced by $100.

    Sir, the GPC for Home Affairs will focus primarily on the Home Team and its relationship with the community in this Committee of Supply. We believe that the Home Team should continue to work hard at integrating the community in its efforts to fight crime in Singapore. Because of the increase of public awareness in crime prevention, we have seen positive results in combating crime in Singapore. We would like to see more done in this regard.

    Sir, the Home Team released its major crime report recently, indicating a drop of over 17% in major offences cases. This is heartening news indeed and the Home Team deserves recognition for a job well done in year 2000. However, there are a couple of disturbing statistics and trends and I would like to ask the Minister to clarify some of these for us. First, for sexual offences, namely, outraging modesty and rape, the decrease has been marginal - 1.6% for rape and 3.3% for outraging modesty. In other words, these offences are still committed with regularity. I am particularly concerned that the two rape/murder cases, one in Woodlands and the other in Bukit Gombak, remain unsolved to this day. Even more disturbing perhaps is that we now have sexual offenders who are using the Internet and chat lines to establish contact with their victims. Even though the figures may still be low, eight rapes and two cases of outraging modesty, they are on the increase, and may increase

Column: 589

further if no action is taken. How will the Home Team respond to this worrying problem? May I suggest that the Home Team embark on a publicity campaign, especially in secondary schools and the like, to warn young people of the potential dangers of becoming too friendly with Internet contacts. Simple measures such as getting them to make sure that their chaperone comes along perhaps should be told to them.

    Second, while I note that house-breaking has registered a 30%-plus drop in the year 2000, the number of break-ins into private properties has actually increased somewhat - 134 cases in year 2000 as compared with 97 in 1999. In percentage terms, the increase is in the region of about 38%. Could the Minister let us know how the Home Team is responding to this worrying trend? Has the Home Team, for example, taken any steps, similar to the ones that have been taken in HDB estates where police officers have actually visited the residential units to provide residents with information and advice about crime prevention? Perhaps similar steps should be taken by the police with respect to private homes and estates.

    Third, I note that foreigners account for roughly 10% of those arrested for crimes in Singapore. While this might seem as a small percentage, it nonetheless comes to a figure of nearly 1,500 foreigners - the majority of them work permit holders or on social visit passes. I should like to know whether we have sufficiently tight controls at our border checkpoints to prevent such criminals from entering Singapore. Do we have good relations with the police forces of other ASEAN countries, South Asian countries and China to improve the screening of foreigners coming to Singapore?

    Sir, I am sure that the Home Team has made Singapore a much safer home for almost everyone. I hope that this year it will be an even safer one for Singaporeans.

    Mr Goh Choon Kang (Marine Parade)(In Mandarin): Sir, last year, the crime rate

Column: 590

was reduced by 14.7% as compared to 1999, and this is very encouraging. Many people are saying that our Home Team has been doing a very good job.

    Maintaining law and order in our society is just as important as our national defence, and we need a very effective force to take care of this matter. Our declining crime rate did not come by chance. It is the result of the efficiency of our Home Team. Last Saturday, I attended the annual meeting of the review committee on the Home Team, which includes the Police, Immigration and CNB officers. Every unit presented its workplans and these are very comprehensive and farsighted plans. That is why I say that the decline in our crime rate did not come by chance.

    Although, generally, the crime rate has reduced, recently we read from the media that there were many cases of juvenile delinquencies, especially young girls involving in fighting and robbery, and there were also a lot of cases of outraging of modesty and rape. This gives the people the impression that there seems to be an increase in the number of juvenile delinquency cases. It is particularly noteworthy that an army officer and a teacher were involved in a series of outraging of modesty cases. There was also one 15-year old girl who made friend with someone on the Internet and subsequently had sexual intercourse with a number of strangers.

    Notwithstanding the statistics released by the police that there were only two outraging of modesty cases arising from Internet acquaintances, there were eight cases of rape. This was significantly more than last year's figure. But these were only reported cases. We do not know how many cases went unnoticed, because no police report was lodged.

    We all know that our young people and students like to go on ICQ and chat room on the Internet. And because of their curiosity, they become easy prey for the criminals. I think the parents and the teachers should take special notice of this. Although such cases are not many, it seems to be on an upward trend. I think

Column: 591

the police should pay more attention to this problem and take some effective measures to counter them.

    Assoc. Prof. Chin Tet Yung: Sir, earlier, I spoke about the need for the Home Team to establish a strong bond with the community. There are several innovative programmes in place to encourage this sort of bonding. In particular, the two-year old Community Safety and Security Programme (CSSP) has taken root in many grassroots organisations. Even school children and stallholders in markets are now involved in CSSP. At last count, over 500 RCs are involved in such a programme. This, again, is a major achievement for the Home Team.

    Where there are grassroots organisations formed, the bonds between the Home Team and the community have been strengthened through the CSSP. However, in the case of new towns, there is frequently a perception among residents that the Home Team has not been visible enough, and that they fear that there is insufficient protection, especially when the policy is now not to build any more Neighbourhood Police Posts (NPPs), but to concentrate on the larger type of Neighbourhood Police Centres (NPCs) and mobile policing rather than static NPP type of policing. Nonetheless, it appears that the traditional concept of the policemen on the beat still strikes a chord of security in many residents.

    Sir, I would like to ask the Minister whether the Home Team could look into how police presence can be improved in new estates, where residents have a natural tendency to feel insecure in their new environment. Would the Minister consider the following:

    (i) reinstate foot patrols or bicycle patrols in new areas where there are many new residents and where the RCs have not yet been formed;

    (ii) purchase more mobile NPPs and station them on a regular basis around the new neighbourhoods; and

    (iii) start house visits early to new residents; in fact, as soon as they move in and, in any case, not later than 6-8 months.

Column: 592



    Sir, such visits and patrols increase police presence significantly and add to the sense of security and well-being among the residents.

    Mr S. Iswaran (West Coast): Sir, the Community Safety and Security Programme (CSSP) was started in 1998, and it brings together the grassroots organisations, the CDCs and residents with the help of the Home Team to address specific areas of concern pertaining to security. I think there are sound principles that underlie this approach. It fundamentally emphasises that safety and security is everyone's responsibility, and it nurtures the spirit of self-help and mutual support within the community. So on all those counts, it is very consistent with Singapore 21 and the idea of active citizenship.

    Sir, the question I have for the Minister is, given that the programme has been in place for over two years now, how well received is it on the ground, particularly amongst the RCs. Also, last year, there was the suggestion that it was going to be extended to schools, and I would like to know how the schools have responded to this initiative, especially as there were some concerns that schools might be somewhat reluctant because they may be stigmatised as having particular problems and that is why they are participating.

    Sir, I am also interested to know how the Ministry assesses the effectiveness of the CSSP. Is it purely by input measures, such as the numbers participating, or are there other ways that we can measure the efficacy? For example, the latest crime statistics show that the elderly have been particular targets for cheating offences. Has there been a response through the CSSP to this particular form of problem?

    Sir, the related issue is police presence which the GPC Chairman, Prof. Chin, has also spoken on. Even as residents come forward to do their bit, they do look to the police to continue to maintain vigilance and protection on the ground. In this regard, police presence and visibility is crucial. The feedback is that residents see less of the men in blue on the ground. They attribute this to closure of NPPs and

Column: 593

also perhaps to a greater emphasis on police patrols by cars, rather than by foot or bicycle. Sir, I do not think that this is confined to just the newer estates. In general, I have received this feedback from various quarters. The visibility of the police has an important deterrence value to would-be criminals but perhaps, more importantly, it has an important assurance value for residents, assurance of security and general safety.

    Sir, I would like to ask the Minister what measures are in place to ensure that the police continue to maintain a certain level of visibility on the ground, particularly in those areas of high human traffic where visibility through foot patrols or bicycle patrols will be much more effective.

    Mr Goh Choon Kang(In Mandarin): Sir, just now, our GPC Chairman, Prof. Chin, talked about a scheme whereby Neighbourhood Police Posts (NPPs) are closed down with the opening of Neighbourhood Police Centres (NPCs). My constituency is one of those affected by this scheme, and I would like to reflect some of the feedback I have got from my residents.

    Since the 1980s when we first started this concept of Neighbourhood Police Post, the NPP has become a familiar feature in our neighbourhood, and it has given the people the impression that the Police is very friendly and pro-residents. Very good relationship has been built up between the Police and the residents, and it has given the residents a sense of security living there.

    However, with this new concept of Neighbourhood Police Centre being implemented, many of these NPPs will be closed down and many people are feeling a sense of loss, as though with the closure of these NPPs, they would lose this sense of security. They do not understand why the Police must make these changes. Some people are concerned that by so doing, it would affect the law and order in the area and would go back to the situation before these Neighbourhood Police Posts were set up. The good relationship previously built up by the

Column: 594

policemen in the NPPs and the residents would then be dampened.

    I hope the Minister would answer these queries.
10.15 am

    The Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Wong Kan Seng): Sir, I thank the Members for their comments on the good work done by the Home Team, and in particular the Police which they talked about - their presence and their relationship with the community, that there is now a very wide level of acceptance of the Police friendliness and the way they have been helping the public, and serving their security and safety needs on the ground.

    As Prof. Chin has mentioned, crime rate has indeed dropped very significantly last year. Last year was in fact a very good year for the Police in that the crime situation was under control, although we still have something like 30,000 cases of seizable offences reported last year. But as a percentage, this is a significant drop of something like 15% from that of 1999. On a per hundred thousand basis, the drop is even more significant, from 924 to 764 cases per 100,000.

    In the year 2000, eight of the nine index crimes fell, compared to 1999. Index crimes are those offences which are used for international comparison purposes on the situation of crimes in other parts of the world. These are selected for their reliability and higher reporting rates. In our context, the nine offences in the index crimes are murder, rape, outraging of modesty, robbery, housebreaking, motor vehicle thefts, snatch thefts, cheating-related offences and rioting.

    Property offences such as housebreaking, robbery, motor vehicle thefts and snatch thefts also fell very significantly, between 14% and 36%. The offences of murder, cheating-related offences, outraging of modesty and rape also declined. But the offence of rioting recorded a slight increase of 4%, after having dropped by close to 33% in 1999, compared to 1998.

Column: 595



    Mr Goh Choon Kang was concerned about youth crime and the situation of young people not knowing about the dangers of Internet chats, and so on, the same concern as expressed by Prof. Chin - that young girls are caught unawares when they engage themselves in IRC chats and eventually get taken advantage of. There has been a slight increase in the number of such cases reported, but the number is still very small. But the main part really is in not just Police having public education campaign on the young people but the parents themselves must play a very important part in ensuring that their children, when they get involved in Internet chats, know what they are doing and educate them of the dangers of meeting strangers in strange places and unaccompanied. There is a Parents Advisory Group on the Internet led by private citizens and the Police will work closely with them, together with the Education Ministry, on educating our young people on the dangers of such Internet chats, which may eventually lead them to trouble.

    But, on the whole, talking about crimes committed by youths, such as shoplifting, theft, rioting, causing serious hurt, these have decreased very significantly. The number of youths arrested for shoplifting, which is a major component of the number of crimes committed by the youth, has decreased by 16%, from 1,300 cases to 1,100 cases in the year 2000. The number of youths arrested for theft, which also includes shoplifting, has also fallen from 2,400 youths to 1,900 youths, and that is a decrease of about 23%.

    So we have seen a significant decrease in the number of youths arrested for shoplifting or theft which includes shoplifting. While that is still quite a large number, I think that with enough of publicity effort on this on the part of the Police to educate the young people, particularly working very closely with the schools to ensure that the students know the rights and wrongs when they go to the shops, and not just be too quick with their fingers and pinch things that do not belong to them and not paying for them, the crimes involving youths and young people have

Column: 596

actually not increased. But I think the perception that we have a problem among the young people that there is an increase in youth crime probably is due to the publicity given by the media whenever a case happens, and when it is reported, people get excited about it. When these cases are highlighted, then, of course people will be concerned. But from the number of young people arrested for crimes, we have not seen an increase but we have seen a significant decrease. Nevertheless, we pay very close attention to making sure that young people do not go wayward and we try to do as much as possible to educate them about the dangers of committing crimes. In my Ministry, we have formed an Inter-Ministerial Committee on Youth Crimes, chaired by Prof. Ho Peng Kee, working together with the Education Ministry, the Ministry of Community Development and Sports, and the other voluntary organisations. The whole idea is to engage the community, plus all those Government agencies that are involved in educating young people or making sure that they do not get into trouble, like MCDS.

    This multi-agency approach actually has worked quite well in that they have come up with many new ideas to cope or deal with this problem of young people committing crimes. They have also worked with this Parents Advisory Group on the Internet. So we should leave it to such initiatives and not get the Police thoroughly involved in every activity or every crime that may impact the public. Really, in the case of young people, the parents themselves should play an important part in educating their own children and not leaving it to others alone.

    There is also a concern expressed by Members that the Police seem to withdraw themselves from the community by setting up Police Centres and closing down police posts, as Mr Goh Choon Kang said. Actually, this idea of a Police Centre increases the presence of Police on the ground. It does not reduce the presence of Police on the ground. The NPPs in the past, we still have them - and by the middle of this year, we would have concluded the phasing over of the Neighbourhood Police Centres taking over a

Column: 597

large part of the NPC system - we still have these NPPs until July, and thereafter we will have the NPCs being the key nodes of the Police presence on the ground, supplemented by some other NPPs that are still in operation. But the difference between the NPP and NPC is that in the past, the NPPs were very static operations. NPP just involved a few officers sitting in the post and from time to time, they went on house visits, they went on their feet or patrolled on their bicycles. And even when they were requested to attend to a crime scene, they just went there and watched and waited for their divisional officers to come. So we thought that was not a very good use of Police resources. For every trained Police Officer should really be right there on the ground the moment something happens and do something about it, and not just waiting for an investigator or somebody else to come from the Division to start the investigation work.

    So this NPC system has allowed us to pool more of our Police officers together in 32 NPCs, so that with the number, they can then do their job more thoroughly when they respond to a particular event or incident. Let me assure Members that with the phasing over to the Neighbourhood Police Centre system, there is no reduction in Police presence on the ground. In fact, the level of Police presence has increased with the NPC. And the Police will make their presence felt in the form of foot patrols, bicycle patrols, vehicle patrols, as there are now more vehicles on the road than when we had the NPP system. These vehicle patrols also allow our Police officers to reach a wider area, instead of just walking on foot and reaching a small part of the estate. With the communication equipment available in the Police vehicles, the patrol vehicles are also deployed to respond to `999' calls whenever there is an incident reported. In addition, the Police Task Force operations and the dog patrols also complement this regular Police force.

    Under the NPC system, we have four officers from each NPC conducting patrols

Column: 598

compared to practically no one doing foot patrols under the NPP system. By July this year, we will have more than 124 officers from the NPC performing such foot patrols island-wide. So the public should see an increase in the number of officers on the ground.

    Prof. Chin asked about the temporary police post that we have deployed, or actually we call them mobile police post. We have deployed these temporary or mobile police posts since 1997. They are basically vehicles and they make stops at selected locations at different times of the day. They are deployed to meet some very transient or very seasonal demands for Police presence, such as when there is a crime-prone area, we will set up a temporary or mobile police post in the particular area. We have now three such temporary police posts, and by the end of this year, we will have another three more. So we will increase the number of temporary police posts by the end of the year.

    Prof. Chin mentioned that the residents of new housing estates are concerned about the sense of safety and security. Let me assure him that the Police is very mindful of this and that is why we will try to build the Police Centres in the new towns such as Sembawang and Chua Chu Kang as soon as possible. By the year 2003, Police Centres will also be built in Sengkang, which is another new housing estate. Even before the Police Centres are set up, the Police will make sure that their presence is felt through the deployment of these temporary police posts. I have also asked our Police Officers to try to work together with HDB to find out who are the new residents who move into the new estates and visit them as soon as possible, to assure them that the Police knows that they have moved in and that they are around and if they need help, there is a particular number which they can call to seek assistance. So that is well in hand. Let me assure Prof. Chin and his constituents that the Police is well aware of their concerns and they will do what they can within the resources to cope with their demand.

    We know that the sense of public safety in Singapore is quite high. At least in the

Column: 599

last survey that the Police conducted - the Police commissioned a private survey firm to conduct a survey in late 1999 - almost 96% of the respondents, including those from the new housing estates, feel that the general security of Singapore is good or, if not, better.
10.30 am

    Mr Goh Choon Kang is worried about the closure of the police posts when we set up police centres. We have to look at the overall deployment of the force, including the siting of the police centres and the police posts. In a few instances, I have noticed that the police post is just about 200 metres away from the new police centre. In fact, there is one instance where the police post is just 20 metres away from the police centre. It does not make sense to have a police centre and the police post almost within one minute of walking distance. So these posts would have to be closed. For example, the one in Braddell Heights will be closed when we set up a new police centre there. But the residents there need not be too worried because the police presence will still be felt on the ground.

    The experience of residents in areas where we have the police centres seems to suggest that they now feel quite comfortable with the new police centre system. And indeed, in those areas where we have the police centres, crime has fallen and more residents are also getting involved in ensuring the safety and security of their own neighbourhood. Two surveys conducted in 1999 and 2000 showed that almost 90% of the residents and grassroots leaders who live in these areas where we have the police centres supported the introduction of the police centres. They also appreciated the fact that police centres deliver more services and have more police presence on the ground than before when we have the police post system. This means that this system is now gaining acceptance and it is only in the old areas where we do not have police centres yet, and people are very used to the police posts where they can just go and chat up with the friendly policeman, that they feel a bit uncomfortable when they see a bigger station

Column: 600

with more officers and they do not know who to keep in touch with, and so on. Let me assure the Member that when we have a police centre, we will also delegate officers to work closely with the grassroots leaders so that the grassroots leaders will know who to contact when they have any request to make.

    Questions were also asked about the Community Safety and Security Programme and how much more involved are residents now in the safety and security of their own neighbourhood. As Prof. Chin has cited the numbers, there are now more than 500 such Community Safety and Security Programmes. This is a programme to directly involve the residents concerned in dealing with the problems of their own areas because each neighbourhood faces different problems. And it is better for the residents themselves to find out how to deal with those problems by working closely with the authorities, whether it is the police or whether it is some other Government agency. And the police will, together with the other Home Team partners, give them whatever resources they need to do their job. But the primary initiative must come from the residents themselves.

    Mr Iswaran's area in West Coast, for example, has a few Community Safety and Security Programmes. But they can be much more active than what they are now. With Mr Iswaran's support and involvement in encouraging them to be more active in looking out for issues and problems that concern them, they will be more effective in increasing the sense of security among the residents. It is important for the advisors on the ground also to play their role, and not just leave it to the RCs and the community organisations, to take their own initiative. If they take an interest, I am sure their residents will take an interest.

    In the case of schools, a year-plus ago, I have asked the Education Ministry to see whether we should not introduce a scheme like that to the schools so that, at least, within the school community, they can help to improve the sense of safety and security among the students and

Column: 601

teachers. And the Home Team took this to the schools, to the Education Ministry, spoke to the principals and many principals were very supportive. Now, we have 42 schools directly involved in the school safety and security programme, and they have come up with many initiatives. Quite a number of them have been publicised, including the safe drive zone within the school's neighbourhood to ensure that when the children come to school, or when they go home, and when there are too many vehicles in the school compound and in the vicinity of the school, how they can ensure the safety of the children who leave or come to the school.

    But numbers alone are not enough, of course. We need to have quality programmes. With these new initiatives and when they come from the residents, they feel that they have identified the problems and found the solution, they feel quite proud when they have achieved something.

    Let me just quote an example here. In March last year, Blks 55 and 56 of Telok Blangah Drive in West Coast GRC, which is also Mr Iswaran's GRC, were hit by a series of deliberate fires that caused substantial damage to the common areas. More seriously, the fires were potential threats to the elderly residents living there.
